content.$t: deadline: 16/1/2018, icon: symphony.svg, owner: Charles, Mark, Richard, Scott, Tom, Jonny. Helen, Rouska, Andrew, summary: The Symphony of Blockchain is an interactive, visual and auditory exploration of Bitcoin, cryptocurrency and the blockchain. It is an ongoing research initiative with a singular aim: to help bring about greater understanding of both blockchain technology and the ever expanding (and contracting) cryptocurrency marketplace.

gsx$owner.$t: Charles, Mark, Richard, Scott, Tom, Jonny. Helen, Rouska, Andrew

gsx$summary.$t: The Symphony of Blockchain is an interactive, visual and auditory exploration of Bitcoin, cryptocurrency and the blockchain. It is an ongoing research initiative with a singular aim: to help bring about greater understanding of both blockchain technology and the ever expanding (and contracting) cryptocurrency marketplace.

title.$t: Press coverage in the Next Web

content.$t: deadline: 17/1/2018, icon: symphony.svg, owner: Rouska, Laurie, Jane, summary: Symphony of Blockchain was featured in The Next Web, the popular online media source for international technology news, business, and culture. In this feature piece, Bitcoin as art: This breath-taking visualization might distract you from the dip, TNW described Symphony of Blockchains as a "mesmerizing live 3D visualization and audio experience that’s not just gorgeous, but also incredibly informative". It recognises that blockchain may be one of the most transformative and disruptive forces in the tech world, but it’s a notoriously difficult concept to get across. This project is a beautiful and functional educational tool that makes it easier for the general public to understand blockchain.

content.$t: icon: symphony.svg, summary: Research starts on Cardano blocks and protocol system. Understand & research the unique features of cardano and how it compares to Bitcoin. What interesting stories does the data show that can be represented and compared visually.

gsx$summary.$t: Research starts on Cardano blocks and protocol system. Understand & research the unique features of cardano and how it compares to Bitcoin. What interesting stories does the data show that can be represented and compared visually.

content.$t: icon: symphony.svg, summary: Research starts on ethereum blocks and protocol system. Understand & research the unique features of ethereum and how it compares to cardano & Bitcoin. What interesting stories does the data show that can be represented and compared visually.

gsx$summary.$t: Research starts on ethereum blocks and protocol system. Understand & research the unique features of ethereum and how it compares to cardano & Bitcoin. What interesting stories does the data show that can be represented and compared visually.

content.$t:
icon: symphony.svg, summary: The first step will be to identify interesting parameters to use in the underlying sound bed. This would involve a process of experimentation and prototyping to see which parameters yield interesting results.

Here are some initial ideas which I think would we should explore:

Spent to unspent transaction ratio. This could be more effective if it's also mirrored in the visual. The sound of transactions which are fully spent could be lower-pitched, low pass filtered to be more muffled and have an echo / reverb. Unspent transactions could be contain more high frequency data and sound more energetic to imply that they have latent energy.

Transaction and block hashes are an interesting source of randomness. They could be used to modulate filters and other sound generation parameters. This could give real uniqueness to the sound of each block.

Using the number of transactions per block to control the volume or intensity of particular parameters could affect the ambient sound bed.

I like the idea of taking parameters from transactions which are closest to the camera so that you can really explore the sound in 3D.

Sounds when hovering over blocks with the mouse would add to the immersion and make it feel more interactive.

gsx$summary.$t:
The first step will be to identify interesting parameters to use in the underlying sound bed. This would involve a process of experimentation and prototyping to see which parameters yield interesting results.

Here are some initial ideas which I think would we should explore:

Spent to unspent transaction ratio. This could be more effective if it's also mirrored in the visual. The sound of transactions which are fully spent could be lower-pitched, low pass filtered to be more muffled and have an echo / reverb. Unspent transactions could be contain more high frequency data and sound more energetic to imply that they have latent energy.

Transaction and block hashes are an interesting source of randomness. They could be used to modulate filters and other sound generation parameters. This could give real uniqueness to the sound of each block.

Using the number of transactions per block to control the volume or intensity of particular parameters could affect the ambient sound bed.

I like the idea of taking parameters from transactions which are closest to the camera so that you can really explore the sound in 3D.

Sounds when hovering over blocks with the mouse would add to the immersion and make it feel more interactive.
